title: Chemical treatment enhances skipping of a mutated exon in the dystrophin gene
patient: The proband (KUCG 797) was a 5-year-old boy born to healthy Japanese parents without any family history of muscle disease. He started to walk independently at 1 year and 4 months of age and his motor development was normal. At the age of 2 years, his serum creatine kinase level was found to be 2,567 IU l−1 (normal <169 IU l−1) in a routine blood examination conducted on admission to hospital. He was referred to Kobe University Hospital to have his dystrophin gene examined for mutations. The mild creatine kinase elevation persisted (1,331–4,740 IU l−1). No muscle weakness or abnormal gait was observed. At the age of 5 years, a muscle biopsy was performed. Informed consent for all study aspects including genetic testing was obtained from the parents, and these studies were approved by our ethics committees.
